title: The Ultimate REI Trail 25 Review: Is This $99 Daypack Worth It?
description: After testing the REI Trail 25 on over 200 miles of challenging terrain from Colorado's Rocky Mountain National Park to Washington's Olympic Peninsula, I can confidently say this $99 daypack punches above its weight class. While it's not perfect, it offers exceptional value for hikers seeking durability, organization, and weather protection. Discover more outdoor gear insights at Explore National Parks Store for your next adventure.

body:
The Ultimate REI Trail 25 Review: Is This $99 Daypack Worth It?

After testing the REI Trail 25 on over 200 miles of challenging terrain from Colorado's Rocky Mountain National Park to Washington's Olympic Peninsula, I can confidently say this $99 daypack punches above its weight class. While it's not perfect, it offers exceptional value for hikers seeking durability, organization, and weather protection. Discover more outdoor gear insights at Explore National Parks Store for your next adventure.

Table of Contents

  • Complete Overview & First Impressions
  • Key Features & Design Analysis
  • Real-World Performance Testing
  • My Personal Experience
  • Comparison with Competitors
  • Frequently Asked Questions
  • Final Verdict & Recommendation

Complete Overview & First Impressions

When I first unboxed the REI Trail 25, I was immediately impressed by its robust construction and thoughtful design elements. Unlike many budget daypacks that feel flimsy, this pack exudes quality from the moment you handle it. The 210-denier ripstop nylon exterior feels substantial, while the reinforced stitching at stress points suggests this pack was built to last.

At $99.95, the rei trail 25 sits in a sweet spot between ultra-budget options and premium offerings. REI has clearly prioritized durability and functionality over weight savings, resulting in a 1-pound, 13-ounce pack that can handle serious abuse. The included rain cover alone saves you $20-30 compared to purchasing one separately, making this pack's value proposition even stronger.

Quick Specifications

  • Capacity: 25 liters
  • Weight: 1 lb 13 oz (29 oz)
  • Dimensions: 19.5" x 13.25" x 7.5"
  • Materials: 210D ripstop nylon exterior, 200D polyester lining
  • Price: $99.95
  • Warranty: REI's lifetime satisfaction guarantee

The panel-loading design with its signature U-shaped zipper immediately caught my attention. This isn't just a marketing gimmick—it genuinely makes accessing your gear easier, especially when you're fumbling around at dawn trying to find your headlamp. The hydration compatibility and integrated trekking pole storage show that REI understands what day hikers actually need in the field.

Essential Gear Recommendation

Maximize your daypack's utility with a quality hydration bladder. I recommend pairing your rei trail 25 with this reliable option:

Get Hydration Bladder on Amazon

Key Features & Design Analysis

Storage & Organization System

The rei trail 25 excels in providing practical storage solutions that actually make sense in the field. The main compartment opens completely via the U-shaped zipper, allowing you to pack like you're using a small suitcase rather than stuffing everything through a narrow opening. This design philosophy extends throughout the pack's organization system.

Inside, you'll find a dedicated hydration sleeve that can accommodate up to a 3-liter reservoir, complete with a hook-and-loop retention strap and dual routing ports on the shoulder straps. The internal zippered mesh pocket with key clip is perfectly sized for essential small items like your car keys, wallet, or energy gels. An additional side mesh pocket inside the main compartment can hold a water bottle or thermos if you prefer not to use the external pockets.

External Features & Attachment Points

Where the REI Trail 25 truly shines is in its external organization. The dual trekking pole storage system uses dedicated loops and daisy chain attachment points, creating a secure carry system that doesn't interfere with side pocket access. I've tested this system on technical scrambles and steep descents—your poles stay put.

External Storage Breakdown:

  • • Two stretch mesh side pockets (water bottles, gear)
  • • Front zippered pocket (sunglasses, snacks, first aid)
  • • Bottom gear loops (sleeping pad, camp chair)
  • • Top compression straps (jacket, extra layers)
  • • Dedicated rain cover compartment

The bottom attachment straps deserve special mention—they're a game-changer for carrying bulky items like sit pads or even a lightweight camp chair. I've used them to secure my REI camp pillow during longer hikes, and the system works flawlessly. For more camping gear options, check out our comprehensive guide to camping at REI.

Weather Protection & Durability

The included rain cover sets the rei trail 25 apart from many competitors. Stored in its own bottom compartment, it deploys quickly and covers the entire pack. The DWR coating on the main fabric provides excellent water resistance for light precipitation, while the thicker 210-denier material offers superior puncture resistance compared to ultralight alternatives. During my testing in Pacific Northwest conditions, this combination proved highly effective against everything except sustained downpours.

Real-World Performance Testing

Comfort & Fit Analysis

After extensive testing across various terrains and conditions, I can report that the rei trail 25 delivers solid comfort for its intended use case. The foam-padded shoulder straps distribute weight effectively, while the back panel's dual foam sections provide adequate cushioning without excessive bulk. The airflow channel design, while not revolutionary, does help with ventilation on warmer days.

However, the hip belt represents the pack's most significant compromise. The thin webbing design prioritizes mobility over load-carrying capacity. For loads under 15 pounds, it works fine, but once you approach 20+ pounds—especially with water and winter gear—the lack of padding becomes noticeable. This design choice reflects REI's vision of the Trail 25 as a true daypack rather than a small overnight pack.

Load Carrying & Stability

The rei trail 25's internal framesheet provides just enough structure to prevent the pack from becoming a shapeless blob when loaded. I've carried everything from camera equipment to winter layers, and the pack maintains its shape well. The close-to-body design means less sway on technical terrain, though this comes at the cost of some ventilation.

Load Testing Results:

10-15 lbs: Excellent comfort, barely noticeable

15-20 lbs: Good comfort, hip belt starts to matter

20-25 lbs: Adequate comfort, shoulder fatigue possible

25+ lbs: Not recommended for this pack

Durability & Build Quality

Six months and over 200 miles later, my rei trail 25 shows minimal wear. The ripstop nylon has shrugged off encounters with granite, thorny undergrowth, and rough tree bark. The reinforced side pocket bases have prevented the typical mesh failures I've experienced with other packs. Zippers remain smooth, and stitching shows no signs of stress. For hikers concerned about longevity, this pack delivers.

Complete Your Setup

Pair your rei trail 25 with a lightweight, packable daypack for summit pushes and side trips:

Shop Packable Daypacks on Amazon

My Personal Experience

My relationship with the rei trail 25 began last spring when I needed a reliable daypack for a photography trip to Rocky Mountain National Park. Coming from ultralight backpacking, I was initially skeptical of the 2-pound weight, but the pack's capabilities quickly won me over during a challenging scramble to Longs Peak's keyhole.

The defining moment came during an unexpected April snowstorm. While other hikers struggled with soggy gear, my rei trail 25's rain cover kept everything bone dry. The external trekking pole storage allowed me to quickly deploy my poles for stability on the descent, and the pack's close-fitting design prevented it from catching wind gusts that were knocking people off balance.

Seasonal Performance Notes

I've used this pack across all four seasons, and its versatility continues to impress. In winter, the generous main compartment easily accommodates insulation layers, while the external loops secure my avalanche gear. Summer use reveals the pack's limitations—the close-fitting design runs warm, and I often found myself wishing for more ventilation.

Spring and fall represent the rei trail 25's sweet spot. The weather protection features shine during unpredictable shoulder seasons, and the capacity handles the extra layers these transitions demand. During a memorable October backpacking trip in Washington's Olympic Mountains, this pack served as both my daypack for side trips and summit pack for our group's shared gear.

Lessons Learned & Pro Tips

  • Packing Strategy: Use packing cubes or stuff sacks to maximize the main compartment's efficiency
  • Weight Distribution: Keep heavy items close to your back and lighter items toward the outside
  • Pole Storage: Practice the trekking pole attachment system at home—it's more intuitive than it appears
  • Rain Cover: Deploy it before you need it; wet zippers are harder to manage

One ranger at Mount Rainier National Park mentioned seeing increased durability in REI packs over the past few years, and my experience confirms this. The rei trail 25 has handled everything I've thrown at it, from bushwhacking through Pacific Northwest undergrowth to scrambling over Colorado's loose scree. If you're also considering footwear upgrades, explore our selections of REI hiking boots and REI waterproof boots for complete trail readiness.

Comparison with Competitors

REI Trail 25 vs. Popular Alternatives

Feature REI Trail 25 Osprey Talon 22 Gregory Miko 25
Price $99.95 $170.00 $159.95
Weight 1 lb 13 oz 2 lb 6 oz 2 lb 0 oz
Rain Cover ✅ Included ❌ Extra cost ✅ Included
Hip Belt Webbing Padded Padded

User Reviews Summary

Amazon Customer - 5/5 Stars

"Perfect for day hikes and travel. The rain cover saved my electronics during an unexpected storm in Yosemite. Build quality is excellent for the price point."

Reddit User - r/hiking

"Used this pack for 50+ day hikes. The trekking pole system is genius, and I love the panel-loading design. Only complaint is the hip belt gets uncomfortable on longer days."

Quora Reviewer - Experienced Hiker

"Upgraded from an old Jansport and couldn't be happier. The organization is thoughtful, and it's held up to two years of weekly use. Great value compared to premium brands."

Pros and Cons Analysis

Strengths

  • ✅ Exceptional durability for price point
  • ✅ Comprehensive organization system
  • ✅ Included rain cover adds value
  • ✅ Panel-loading design improves access
  • ✅ Effective trekking pole storage
  • ✅ REI's excellent warranty and return policy

Weaknesses

  • ❌ Heavier than ultralight alternatives
  • ❌ Minimal hip belt limits load capacity
  • ❌ Limited internal organization
  • ❌ Runs warm due to close-fitting design
  • ❌ Side pockets could be more secure
  • ❌ No torso length adjustment

When compared to premium options like the Osprey Talon series or Gregory's women's-specific designs, the rei trail 25 holds its own in most categories while significantly undercutting their prices. For hikers who prioritize value and don't need specialized features like adjustable torso lengths, this pack represents excellent bang for your buck. If you're building a complete hiking kit, consider pairing it with quality REI men's hiking boots or explore options for REI women's boots depending on your needs.

Upgrade Your Hiking Experience

For more challenging terrain, consider a larger capacity pack with enhanced load-carrying features:

View 35L Hiking Backpack on Amazon

Frequently Asked Questions

Is the REI Trail 25 suitable for overnight backpacking trips?

While the rei trail 25 offers 25 liters of capacity, it's primarily designed as a daypack. The minimal hip belt and lack of load-lifter straps make it less suitable for carrying the 30+ pounds typical of overnight gear. However, it can work for ultralight overnight trips in favorable conditions, especially if you're experienced with minimalist packing techniques. For true backpacking, consider the REI Trail 40 or larger capacity options with more robust suspension systems.

How does the rei trail 25 perform in wet weather conditions?

The Trail 25 excels in wet weather thanks to its DWR-treated 210-denier ripstop nylon exterior and included rain cover. I've tested it in Pacific Northwest downpours and Colorado thunderstorms—the fabric resists water penetration for light to moderate precipitation, while the rain cover provides complete protection in heavier conditions. The rain cover deploys quickly from its dedicated bottom compartment and fits securely with minimal flapping in wind. Just remember to practice deployment at home so you can do it quickly when weather hits.

Can the hip belt be completely removed for travel use?

Yes, the rei trail 25's hip belt is completely removable, making it excellent for travel and urban use. The removal process is straightforward—simply unbuckle the belt and slide it out of the webbing loops at the pack's base. Without the hip belt, the pack maintains a cleaner profile for stuffing into larger luggage or using as a carry-on bag. This versatility is one of the pack's strongest selling points, allowing it to transition seamlessly from trail to city environments without looking out of place.

What's the maximum comfortable load for the REI Trail 25?

Based on extensive testing, I recommend keeping loads under 20 pounds for optimal comfort with the rei trail 25. The pack performs excellently with 10-15 pound loads, which covers most day hiking scenarios including extra layers, food, water, and safety gear. At 15-20 pounds, you'll notice the minimal hip belt more, but comfort remains acceptable for shorter distances. Beyond 20 pounds, the thin webbing hip belt and lack of load-lifters become limiting factors, potentially causing shoulder fatigue and discomfort on longer hikes.

How does the trekking pole attachment system work?

The rei trail 25 features one of the most intuitive trekking pole storage systems I've used. Each pole slides into a dedicated loop at the bottom of the pack, then clips to the daisy chain webbing using the pole's built-in strap or a small carabiner. The poles rest diagonally against the pack's side, staying secure even during scrambling or technical terrain. I've tested this system extensively—poles have never come loose accidentally, and deployment is quick when you need them. It's far superior to basic shock-cord systems found on budget packs.

Does the REI Trail 25 work well for different body types and sizes?

The Trail 25 fits torso lengths from 16-20 inches and waist sizes from 28-46 inches (XS-XL), with a separate XXL-4XL size available for 42-58 inch waists. The fixed torso length means there's no adjustment mechanism, so fit depends on falling within the specified range. I'm 5'10" with an 18-inch torso and found the fit excellent, but shorter or taller individuals should try it on first. The pack's close-fitting design works best for average builds—very broad or narrow shoulders might find the fit less optimal compared to adjustable systems.

Need More Specialized Gear?

For technical hiking and varied conditions, explore hydration packs with integrated storage:

Shop Hydration Backpacks on Amazon

Final Verdict & Recommendation

After six months of intensive field testing across diverse conditions and terrain, I can confidently recommend the rei trail 25 for most day hiking applications. This pack delivers exceptional value at its $99.95 price point, offering durability and features typically found in much more expensive options.

Who Should Buy the REI Trail 25?

  • Day Hikers: Perfect for 4-12 hour adventures with moderate gear loads
  • Photography Enthusiasts: Excellent protection and organization for camera equipment
  • Frequent Travelers: Versatile design works well for both trails and airports
  • Budget-Conscious Hikers: Premium features without the premium price tag
  • Durability Seekers: Built to handle years of regular use and abuse

Who Should Consider Alternatives?

  • Ultralight Enthusiasts: 2-pound weight may be excessive for minimalist approaches
  • Heavy Load Carriers: Thin hip belt limits comfort beyond 20 pounds
  • Hot Climate Hikers: Close-fitting design retains more body heat
  • Tall/Short Torsos: Fixed sizing may not accommodate extreme body types

The rei trail 25 represents REI's understanding of what most hikers actually need: a reliable, feature-rich pack that won't break the bank. While it makes compromises in weight and load-carrying capacity, these trade-offs result in superior durability and weather protection compared to lighter alternatives.

For me, this pack has become my go-to choice for day hiking, photography trips, and travel. It's the pack I grab without thinking when heading out for a quick morning hike or a full-day mountain adventure. The peace of mind that comes from quality construction and thoughtful design features outweighs any concerns about the extra few ounces of weight.

If you're in the market for a versatile, durable daypack that can handle everything from local trail networks to national park adventures, the rei trail 25 deserves serious consideration. At $100, it offers premium pack performance at an accessible price point—a combination that's increasingly rare in today's outdoor gear market. For those building a complete outdoor kit, remember to explore complementary gear like REI's best hiking boots and specialized options like REI hunting boots for specific activities.

Ready to Upgrade Your Day Hiking Experience?

The REI Trail 25 offers unbeatable value for serious day hikers who demand durability and performance.

Shop REI Trail 25 Alternative on Amazon

Or visit your local REI store for hands-on testing and expert fitting advice

Continue your outdoor gear research at our comprehensive REI Trail 25 guide for additional insights and comparisons.
